Hi David,
 
My preference would be to never grind development to a halt.  But, I would
be aggressive about writing tests for all new development and all bug fixes.
Once your team is in this habit for a while you'll be well on your way.
Periodically you might use a code coverage tool to identify gaping holes in
your testing and schedule a couple of person-days to plug them up.  Another
way to prioritize new test development for old code is to ask yourselves
"what are we most concerned will break?" and then test that.
 
You'll never have a "fully tested product" -- I don't believe there is such
a thing.  There will always be many more tests that could be there, no
matter how many you write.  But, every well-conceived test helps a little
more.
 
Kevin
 
 

-----Original Message-----
From: David M. Goudreau [mailto:david_goudreau@...]
Sent: Friday, March 16, 2001 3:58 PM
To: JUnit Mailing List
Subject: [junit] Implementing JUnit AFTER development has started...


Does anyone have any opinions, suggestions or approaches as to how to best
implement JUnit AFTER development has started?  We have a significant code
base already and we're trying to move to JUnit.  What issues did you have
when trying this yourself?  Was your testing hierarchy exactly the same as
your application package structure?  Did you start only using JUnit with new
development or with bugs as well?  Or did you take a month off and have
everyone write JUnit tests?  Any help would be greatly appreciated.
 
 
-dmg
